G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as this action involves modification of a custody and parenting-time judgment.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as this action involves modification of a custody and parenting-time judgment.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 8 because both parties and the child reside within this jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Such a modification is consistent with Sofia’s best interests, which is the paramount consideration under G.L. c. 208, § 31.

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: A modification of custody or parenting time requires a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the proposed modification will serve the best interests of the child. (See *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The case discusses an initial custody and visitation determination in a divorce judgment, not a post-judgment modification of custody or parenting time. The opinion repeatedly applies only the general “best interests of the children” standard and does not mention or require a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances as a prerequisite to altering a prior custody or visitation order. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children] should be the controlling consideration.’… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question…”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: A modification of custody or parenting time requires a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the proposed modification will serve the best interests of the child. (See *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)).
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The Schechter opinion discusses standards for initial custody and visitation determinations and reiterates that custody decisions must promote the child’s best interests, but it does not articulate the distinct, two-pronged standard for *modification* of an existing custody or parenting time order. The ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement comes from Massachusetts modification jurisprudence (e.g., Rolde), not from this case. Schechter is therefore good authority on best-interests analysis and abuse-related presumptions, but not on the modification standard itself.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In Massachusetts the focus in a custody dispute between parents is not on their personal rights but on the welfare of the child.… ‘[I]n deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare.’ Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 402 (1981).”

*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.proposition: The decline in Sofia’s school attendance and academic performance constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the original judgment (*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000); G.L. c. 208, § 28).
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Zia is a paternity/custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, not a post‑judgment modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and it does not analyze what constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances.” While the judge comments on the child’s stimulation, day care attendance, and the mother’s approach to education, the case never frames school attendance or academic performance as a change from a prior judgment or as satisfying a modification standard. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that a later decline in school attendance and performance constitutes a material and substantial change under § 28.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . . In the instant matter, the judge was cognizant of, and made reference to, the directive in G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), that she preserve, to the extent possible, the relationship between the child and the primary caretaker.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Defendant’s failure to cooperate in fostering Sofia’s educational well-being violates the obligations of shared legal custody (*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion defines ‘joint legal custody’ as shared responsibility over decisions regarding education and other welfare matters, but it does not address any parent’s *failure to cooperate* with those obligations nor hold that such failure constitutes a violation of shared legal custody. The case is about initial allocation of legal and physical custody and removal to Greece, not enforcement or breach of joint legal custody duties. Thus it provides background definition, not authority for the specific proposition about a defendant’s failure to foster a child’s educational well-being violating shared legal custody obligations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare in matters of education, medical care, emotional, moral and religious development.’ As we have said, he awarded physical custody, or possession of the children, to the wife.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Defendant’s failure to cooperate in fostering Sofia’s educational well-being violates the obligations of shared legal custody (*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards and emphasizes that a parent’s efforts to alienate a child from the other parent are relevant to custody determinations. However, it does not specifically address shared legal custody obligations regarding cooperation in a child’s educational well-being. The case is about physical custody and parental alienation, not about a legal duty to cooperate over educational decisions, so it does not clearly support the specific proposition claimed.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See … Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 244 (2000) (custody to parent willing to respect other parent’s role in child’s life)… The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term…”

*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.proposition: Shared legal custody requires joint responsibility for decisions affecting the child’s welfare, including education. (See *Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (1976)).
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion is about appellate procedure and the right to cross-examine a guardian ad litem in a custody dispute. It does not discuss or define shared or joint legal custody, nor does it address the scope of parental decision-making authority (such as educational decisions) under shared legal custody. The proposition about shared legal custody and joint responsibility for decisions affecting the child’s welfare is therefore not supported by this case.
*Gilmore v. Gilmore*, 369 Mass. 598 (197.relevant_excerpt: “In a custody proceeding, a judge makes a determination as to what is in the best interests of the child on the basis of facts presented at trial as well as facts gathered by the court-appointed investigators. The need for accurate, objective information is of foremost importance in this process. In order to determine adequately the reliability and accuracy of a report, we believe that, as a matter of sound judicial policy, the parties should have the opportunity to rebut the report, including the right to cross-examine the investigator.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court must consider the child’s physical, emotional, and educational needs (*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard and, in doing so, expressly focuses on the child’s physical, medical, educational, and daily needs when structuring the custody arrangement. While the court does not articulate a separate, explicit rule that a judge ‘must’ consider physical, emotional, and educational needs in every case, its reasoning assumes that these categories of needs are core components of the best-interests analysis. Thus the case is reasonably good authority that the court’s custody determination requires consideration of the child’s physical and educational (and by implication emotional) needs.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: The judge’s custody award was based on his conclusion that these arrangements were in the best interests of the child. This conclusion was based, in turn, on a number of findings, including, inter alia, that the mother provides well for Kali’s physical needs, is concerned with her health and educational issues, and is the one who “preoccupies herself” with Kali’s care regarding clothing, hygiene, doctor’s appointments, and child care providers… that the mother is more “attuned” to Kali’s medical, educational, and daily needs and is better able to provide for Kali’s welfare and physical needs during the week.

*Morrow v. Morrow*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: Ensuring Sofia’s regular school attendance and access to tutoring is essential to her best interests and academic development (*Morrow v. Morrow*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (2000)).
*Morrow v. Morrow*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns civil service discipline for a municipal employee’s off‑duty misconduct and whether there is a nexus between that conduct and his fitness for his job. It does not address child custody, best interests of a child, school attendance, or academic development. The proposition about ensuring a child’s regular school attendance and tutoring is unrelated to the facts, issues, or holding of this case, so the citation does not support it.
*Morrow v. Morrow*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt: “The commission was, thus, required by this statute to focus on what effect Baldasaro’s reprehensible conduct had on his continuing fitness to perform his job as a heavy equipment operator… Here… the commission was apparently satisfied that the employee had sustained his burden of showing that there was no significant correlation between his conduct and his continuing fitness to perform his job as a heavy equipment operator.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Modifying the current judgment to grant Plaintiff final authority over educational matters or to reduce Defendant’s parenting time on school nights is appropriate to address these concerns (*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a relocation dispute and an improper change of physical custody from the mother to the father. The Appeals Court reverses the change in custody and authorizes the mother’s relocation while keeping custody with her; it does not discuss modifying a judgment to give one parent final decision‑making authority over education or reducing the other parent’s school‑night parenting time as a remedy. Thus, it does not provide authority for modifying legal custody or weeknight parenting time in the way the proposition describes.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “We remand for the entry of a judgment that the custody of the parties’ minor child remain with the mother, that she may relocate with the child to Rhode Island, ‘and for such further proceedings consistent with this opinion relative to time and conditions of visitation.’ Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. at 558. In the absence of agreement, the Probate Court may consider whether it is in Caleb’s best interest to conclude the current school term in Northborough and to begin the next school term in Providence forthwith.”
